executive_summary: Volatile returns for cutting tool and machine tool accessory manufacturers are occurring thanks to difficult operating conditions caused by supply chain disruptions and poor macroeconomic conditions associated with COVID-19. These have all challenged the industry's growth during the period. Moreover, these declines were amplified by the industry's dependence on industrial markets, such as manufacturing, oil and gas. Industry-wide revenue fell at a CAGR of 0.6% to $6.5 billion over the past five years, including a 1.5% decrease in 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Cutting tool and machine tool accessory manufacturers will continue benefiting from an economic recovery, with declining import penetration and renewed industrial activity lifting prospects over the coming years. Growing demand for cutting tool and machine tool accessories will be derived from rising nonresidential building activity. Despite this growth, lower operational costs in countries such as China and Mexico will continue to prompt operators to use offshore facilities, reducing domestic companies' ability to keep up with foreign competition. Industry revenue will nonetheless fall at a CAGR of 0.1% to $6.5 billion over the next five years.

Import penetration into the manufacturing sector has increased amid a strong US dollar, making industry goods relatively more expensive than foreign-made products. More and more domestic demand has been satisfied by imported cutting tool and machine tool accessories from countries such as Germany and Taiwan, which can manufacture tools at lower prices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Since the industry's major downstream markets are manufacturing industries, the industrial production index is an indicator of demand for cutting tool and machine tool accessories. The industrial production index and private investment in metalworking machinery will both steadily grow moving forward, which will bolster the industry's major downstream markets, including machine shops and manufacturing. Demand from major downstream markets will help offset declines associated with offshoring and import competition.

Imports will fall over the next five years as the trade-weighted index, which measures the value of the US dollar, declines. Domestic goods will become relatively more affordable, boosting exports and staving off import competition. A declining US dollar will also help to offset higher costs associated with domestic manufacturing since many operators' are unable to achieve economies of scale. Since industry goods are so specialized, operators must differentiate their products through price or quality.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economies of Scale Remain Out of Reach
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The specialized nature of cutting tool and machine tool accessories means most enterprises only run one business location, employing a handful of workers and servicing a local industrial market. This creates a highly fragmented landscape and prevents operators from expanding and developing economies of scale. This trend will continue over the next five years, and manufacturers that aren't able to serve a local consumer base will be forced to exit the industry.

Operators primarily sell cutting tool and machine tool accessories to other manufacturing industries. Low-cost labor and lighter regulations in countries such as China and Mexico will continue prompting manufacturers to move facilities abroad. This leaves operators with a smaller consumer base and heightens competition among an already fragmented industry. Manufacturers will increasingly offshore facilities to take advantage of low production costs, adding to import competition.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures accessories and attachments for cutting tools, such as small knives and drilling bits. It also manufactures accessories for machine tools such as mechanical clampers. Operators may also provide custom fabrication and repair work on a contract basis.
key_trends: Numerous US companies shifted manufacturing operations overseas. Low-cost labor and lighter regulations in countries such as China and Mexico will continue prompting manufacturers to move facilities abroad.
Industry items are increasingly specialized. Manufacturers must distinguish their commodities through either price or quality to spur demand growth.
The Association for Manufacturing Technology (AMT) lobbies for favorable standards and regulations that enable US-made machinery to be more easily exported to overseas markets.
Federal law requires manufacturers to report export sales. Exports valued at $2,500 or more must be reported to Automated Export System (AES).
Steel prices will decrease in 2023, representing a potential opportunity for manufacturers. Steel is a significant input when producing cutting tools and machine tool accessories.

Consumers demand more sustainable production practices. Clean and renewable energy producers provide environmentally friendly energy sources for various downstream markets, including the manufacturing sector.
Machine tool accessories can be generic without compromising quality. These products face heavier import penetration than cutting accessories.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumer demand for other markets, such as the mining industry, comes from increased demand for more green technology.

Car and automobile manufacturers use cutting tool and machine tool accessories to manufacture structural and moving parts. New car sales have plummeted recently, causing demand from car manufacturers to fall.

COVID-19 disrupted domestic and international air travel, reducing demand for airplane production. Air travel fell significantly in 2020 as consumers stayed at home or traveled by car to abide by social distancing guidelines.

Consumers have demanded more sustainable production practices, which often begin with sourcing clean energy. Clean and renewable energy producers provide environmentally friendly sources of energy for various downstream markets, including the manufacturing sector.

products_and_services.product_description: Small cutting accessories are manufacturers' primary product offering. These accessories are attached to a tool and include small knives, milling cutters, high-speed steel end mills and blade cutters. They also include drilling bits such as twist drills, gun drills and counterbores. Solid round tools, such as mills and drills, are expanding rapidly as demand for lighter tools grows. This product segment also includes threading tools including blanks, tips and inserts.

Tool holders are used to mount the cutting tools in the machine tool. This holder includes tracer and tapering attachments, lathe chucks and all other attachments and accessories. Taps work as a cutting tool by removing material from a workpiece. These include taps and precision ground carbide indexable and throwaway inserts for machine tools.

Other machine tool accessories, services and tertiary activities that manufacturers provide include the resale of products bought and sold, repair work and contract labor performed on materials provided by others. Other tools include parts for metal cutting tools and other metal cutting machine tools.

tier_2_suppliers: Iron Ore Mining in the US
Molybdenum & Metal Ore Mining in the US

Metal Stamping & Forging in the US
Screw, Nut & Bolt Manufacturing in the US

Industrial Supplies Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: California houses the largest share of the US population
demand_determinants.determinant_description: California houses the largest share of the US population.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Manufacturers in the state have an extensive customer base
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Manufacturers in the state have an extensive customer base.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: External competition is derived from import penetration
demand_determinants.determinant_description: External competition is derived from import penetration. Companies offshore their manufacturing facilities to countries with low wage costs.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Excellent product performance will provoke brand loyalty
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Excellent product performance will provoke brand loyalty. Clients come to associate specific manufacturers' products with longevity and dependability.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Only one major player dominates among other manufacturers
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Only one major player dominates among other manufacturers.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Import penetration into the manufacturing sector has increased amid a strong US dollar.
Numerous US companies have shifted manufacturing operations overseas to take advantage of lower wage costs and lighter regulations when it comes to industrial waste.

Favorable trade conditions created by the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) have spurred exports to Canada and Mexico, which are primary export destinations for US-made cutting tools and tool accessories.
Manufacturing in emerging economies has created demand for domestically made cutting tools and accessories.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region gives manufacturers access to Canada, the largest export destination for cutting tools and tool accessories. Being located close to key export destinations and downstream users lower transportation costs.
The region has the highest concentration of iron and steel mills, which are key inputs for cutting tool and machine tool accessories.

The West accounts for the second-largest share of cutting tool and tool accessory manufacturers in 2023, with California housing most establishments in the region. This is largely a product of California's large trade volume and significant manufacturing base. California also houses the largest share of the US population, giving manufacturers in the state an extensive customer base.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The GHGRP requires manufacturers with significant greenhouse gas emissions to report greenhouse gas data and other relevant information. This regulation is in place to find ways to cut emissions, conserve energy and raise awareness of current and potential problems associated with climate change.
Federal law requires manufacturers to use the Automated Export System (AES) to report exports valued at $2,500 or more.
The National Fire Prevention Association (NFPA) sets standards regarding factory safety and product limitations.
Health and safety guidelines were established in 2020 amid COVID-19. Such guidelines advised temporary social distancing and ongoing additional sanitation measures within facilities.

barriers_points.barrier_description: While employees are not required to have a license to operate machinery, a high level of metalworking specialization and skills are necessary.

basis_points.basis_description: External competition is derived from import penetration. Companies offshore their manufacturing facilities to countries with low wage costs.
Excellent product performance will provoke brand loyalty. Clients come to associate specific manufacturers' products with longevity and dependability.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Access to Skilled Workers and Raw Materials
concentration_points.concentration_description: Companies that cannot negotiate beneficial contracts with suppliers of raw materials won't able to reduce costs and increase efficiency, contributing to fragmentation.
Sufficient skilled labor are forced to exit the industry. The wage level is difficult to increase significantly.
New entrants can take advantage of low barriers to entry since there is a lack of regulations. This lowers industry concentration.
New entrants may be deterred by high start-up costs, though.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases will account for 33.8% of industry revenue in 2023. Purchase costs represent the largest expense and consist of raw inputs such as steel and other nonferrous metals. Steel and other metal prices have increased during the period. Purchases' share of revenue fell because of high profit and other costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While employees are not required to have a license to operate machinery, a high level of metalworking specialization and skills are necessary. Despite some streamlining of production, labor remains central and one of the costliest expenditures for manufacturers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations. However, a low rate of growth in technology can also create exposure for incumbents as the trajectory of innovation in other markets could lead to unforeseen competitive disadvantages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: MANUFACTURERS ARE SENSITIVE TO CHANGES IN INDUSTRIAL ACTIVITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Manufactures experience high volatility due to a high dependence on industrial markets. Reduced industrial demand initially resulted from a decline in manufacturing activity in Asia, causing a sharp decline in oil prices and future contraction of industrial activity. A resurgence in global industrial growth spurred expansion among domestic manufacturers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTY PLAYS A BIG ROLE IN TOOL ACCESSORY MANUFACTURING
volatility_points.volatility_description: The pandemic increased volatility in 2020, instigating major changes in revenue for manufacturers. Sharp drops in commodity prices coincided with reduced global industrial activity and supply chain disruptions. Since manufacturers supply a diverse range of industrial markets, this broad economic contraction had an outsized effect on businesses.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Small cutting accessories are manufacturers' primary product offering. These accessories are attached to a tool and include small knives, milling cutters, high-speed steel end mills and blade cutters. They also include drilling bits such as twist drills, gun drills and counterbores. Solid round tools, such as mills and drills, are expanding rapidly as demand for lighter tools grows. This product segment also includes threading tools including blanks, tips and inserts. Most products in this segment are made of steel and other iron alloys. Due to the popularity of these products, it has taken up more space in the market during the period.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Imports Threaten Tool Holders and Taps
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Tool holders are used to mount the cutting tools in the machine tool. This holder includes tracer and tapering attachments, lathe chucks and all other attachments and accessories. Taps work as a cutting tool by removing material from a workpiece. These include taps and precision ground carbide indexable and throwaway inserts for machine tools. Tool holders and taps are types of machine tool accessories. Machine tool accessories can be generic without compromising quality much, so this segment faces heavier import penetration than cutting accessories.

Other machine tool accessories, services and tertiary activities that manufacturers provide include the resale of products bought and sold, repair work and contract labor performed on materials provided by others. Other tools include parts for metal cutting tools and other metal cutting machine tools.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by import penetration from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Imports have a strong pull on operations. Imports reduce demand for US-based companies.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Low-cost imports put downward pressure on selling prices and hurt US companies.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: A jump in steel prices typically decreases downstream demand for industry products.

FAQs.question: Has your company located in proximity to its key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Companies tend to be located new large distribution centers like the Great Lakes, the Mid Atlantic and the West Coast.

FAQs.question: Does your company use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of manufacturing, sales, inventory?
How does your company invest in technology, such as 3D printing, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: The best performing operators tend to have the most efficient manufacturing techniques.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Health and safety measures are key to limiting the threat of damaging lawsuits. Increased health and safety measures increase operating costs for the industry.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Trade associations are strong advocates for companies and help support some of the tariffs that protect the industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit has fluctuated alongside volatile demand and input prices.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects requiring that require capital financing on the horizon?
FAQs.answer: Typically, companies manufacture small and specific products that do not require specifically heavy debt financing.

FAQs.question: Is your technical expertise to a world standard? How do you achieve and maintain good product quality?
FAQs.answer: Access to the latest technologies during upstream and downstream production enables operators to innovate in product capabilities or specifications.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that all staff are thoroughly knowledgeable about the products? What is your training process like?
FAQs.answer: Successful operators have strong technical knowledge of their products and customers' needs.

FAQs.question: Do you have systems in place to keep standards high and continually updating? Have you had any past issues regarding quality?
FAQs.answer: Operators should maintain detailed and extensive quality-control systems to provide high-quality goods and services.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in the value of the US dollar affected demand? How do you expect the value of the dollar to affect your company over the next year?
FAQs.answer: A strong dollar, reflected in a rising trade-weighted index, makes exports more expensive in global markets.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by changes in demand from residential construction? How much of your business comes from this sector?
FAQs.answer: While residential construction is not the largest market for industry products, increased spending does support demand for certain products.

FAQs.question: Do you experience any competition from imports? Do you experience much domestic demand?
FAQs.answer: Increased import penetration tends to impede demand for industry products.
